Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Undergraduate Research in Estuarine and Coastal Marine Systems
Award.AbstractNarration: Duke University will host a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site located at the Duke Marine Laboratory in Beaufort, NC. The program supports internships for 9 students each summer who conduct independent research projects during a 10-week research program that includes seminars in marine sciences, field trips and a series of workshops. Students will live in Marine Laboratory dormitories and take their meals in the dining hall. Students will have a choice of advisors in the general research areas of (1) sensory physiology, ecology and behavior, (2) molecular biology and genetics, and (3) coastal and estuarine physical processes. Throughout the program there will be sessions on safety, scientific ethics, scientific writing, oral and poster presentations, and graphics skills, graduate school and non-academic science careers. The final week will involve completion of a scientific manuscript on the student's research project and a final oral presentation. Co-curricular activities include a Marine Laboratory-sponsored seminar program, participation in selected field trips. The proposed REU is organized to train students to frame scientific research questions, to design and undertake laboratory and field work to address these research questions, and to develop the skills to communicate the results of their research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary 2015-2019

The four objectives of the Duke University Marine Laboratory REU program include:

1)     Development of a peer-group environment, in which students work independently on a focused research project.

2)     Training of students in basic research, communication skills in scientific writing and poster formats, and scientific ethics.

3)     Engagement of students in a mentored research process from conception of an original research question to project design, implementation, analysis, and communication.

4)     Informing students about scientific career paths, especially in ocean sciences.

            Target students were minorities who were majoring in science, and who were rising sophomores, juniors, and seniors.  To this end, the Marine Laboratory partnered Savannah State University (SSU). Additional recruiting occurred through web-based advertising and from the 34 schools that are affiliated with the Marine Laboratory in the Marine Sciences Educational Consortium. We received 1255 applications and selected 45 students (9 each summer) to participate in the program. The percentage of minority participants was 38%, and the percentage of students from colleges/universities lacking a Ph.D. program was 47%.  Students completed a research project, presented 3 oral reports on their projects and wrote papers in the form of a scientific manuscript on their project.  They attended sessions on poster and graphic presentation, manuscript preparation, careers in science, and ethical use of animals in scienc. Eight papers were published in the peer reviewed scientific journals and 11 presentations were made at scientific meetings
